column4: SIXTH ANNUAL MEETING of WOMEN AGENTS _ _ _ _ O _ _ _ _ TO BE HELD AT UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE KNOXVILLE, TENN. APRIL 16 - 21, 1917.
column28: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
column29: The typewritten pamphlet includes the daily meeting schedule for the Sixth Annual Meeting of Tennessee's Women Home Demonstrating Agents at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville, April 16 - 21, 1917. The meetings included a variety of home demonstration topics, ranging from canning, food preservation, beeskeeping to textile laboratory work. The last page (page 4) includes the lists of visiting instructors and the counties in Tennessee represented by the agents.
column30: 1 pamphlet (4 pages) ; 22 cm.

column4: Victory Luncheon --- Hermitage Hotel, Nashville, Tennessee, April 5, 1918.
column24: Council of National Defense (Washington, D.C.). Woman's Committee. Tennessee Division.
column28: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
column29: A program booklet printed in black ink with fancy fonts for a luncheon, [organized] by Virginia P Moore as the Home Economics Director, Federal Food Administration for Tennessee and the Food Director, Tennessee Division, Women's Committee, Council of National Defense. Front page includes 'Dr. Anna Howard Shaw, Chairman, Women's Committee National Council Defense, Washington, D.C., Honor Guest.', also the well-known suffragist and a close colleague of Susan B. Anthony. Page [2] includes the luncheon's menu. Page [3] includes the 'toasts' listing of two reports' titles, "Production of food in our homes" and "Conservation of food in our homes' from Women of West, Middle and East Tennessee. The toast mistress is listed as "Home Economics Director, Federal Food Administration for Tennessee, and Food Director, Tennessee Division, Woman's Committee, Council of National Defense", with a handwritten script in pencil of Moore's name under 'Toast Mistress'. Moore wrote with a fountain pen in blue 'see note" on this page. Page [4] Moore's noted in blue ink, "I would not permit my name to appear on the program as no other name appeared. I should have according to Mrs Ida Belle Wilson and others who asked me to do this. Mama wrote my name in. I was well known by the things I represent. Virginia P. Moore, 1918." This luncheon is an evidence of home demonstration agents' contribution to the war effort in lieu of food production and conservation and Tennessee women's connection to the Women's Rights Movement in the United States.
column30: 1 pamphlet (4 pages) ; 18 cm.

column4: Early Home Demonstration Work in the South.
column28: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
column29: A typewritten text in black ink on onionskin paper, with corrections made in handwriting with pencil and in blue ink, especially for the author's name. Possibly a lecture written by Moore addressing the history of home demonstration work in Southern United States, the history of canning clubs and home demonstration work in Florida, including some history of home demonstration work in the U.S. in general, with a mention of Dr. Seaman A. Knapp, the founder of home demonstration work, and the Smith-Lever Bill, 1914.
column30: 4 leaves of pages ; 28 cm.
column47: Canning and preserving -- Societies, etc. -- History.

column28: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

column28: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
column29: Leave [1]. A typewritten text in black ink written by Moore, with her name penned in blue. The outline includes Moore's home demonstration activities by month. Leave [2]. column28: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

Moore (first on the left) with nine girls from Karns High School Club demonstrating processing and canning tomatoes in the yard of Netta Butler, the club's president's home. The girls demonstrate the use of canning tools, featuring the can seamer and pressure cooker by El Flo's Home Cannery Co., Hickory, N.C., a scale, cans, tomatoes' peeling and coring. On the grass are two full baskets of fresh tomatoes.
